questions.prompt: This representation of quantum mechanics splits a Hamiltonian into a free part that is solvable and a perturbation part that contains complex system dynamics.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this representation that unifies the Heisenberg ["HIGH"-zin-bairg] and Schrödinger [SHRAY-ding-ur] pictures.
A.answer: interaction picture (or Dirac picture)

B.question: In the interaction picture, these things and state vectors are both time-dependent.  These things must be Hermitian ["her-mission"] so that their associated observables have real values.
B.answer: operators

C.question: The interaction picture is used in derivations of this physicist's "golden rule."   Spin one-half particles such as electrons are named for this physicist.

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about Byzantine emperors who returned to the throne after being deposed:

A.question: This Byzantine emperor, the last from the Heraclian [huh-"RACK"-lee-un] dynasty, was known as "the slit-nosed" because his nose was amputated when he was deposed and exiled to Crimea.
A.answer: Justinian II (or Ioustinianos II; accept Justinian Rhinotmetos or Justinian Rhinotmetus; prompt on "Justinian (the Slit-Nosed)" or "Rhinontmetos" or "Rhinotmetus")

B.question: The Fourth Crusade returned to the throne this emperor from the A ngelos dynasty, who had been deposed and blinded by his brother Alexios III.
B.answer: Isaac II Angelos (or Isaakios II prompt on "Isaac (Komnenos Angelos)" or "Isaakios (Komnenos Angelos)")

C.question: The Isaurian emperor Zeno, who was briefly deposed by Basiliscus, ruled during the deposition of this last Western Roman Emperor, who himself was deposed by the barbarian general Odoacer [OH-doh-"ACE"-ur].
C.answer: Romulus Augustus (or Romulus Augustulus; prompt on "Romulus" or "Augustulus")

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-name these literary detectives associated with Oxford:

A.question: This creation of Dorothy Sayers is an aristocratic detective who help s his future wife, Harriet Vane, root out the author of poison pen letters to Oxford dons in Gaudy Night.
A.answer: Lord Peter (Death Bredon) Wimsey (accept either underlined name; accept 17th Duke of Denver)

B.question: Ronald Knox argued that references in "The Adventure of the Missing Three -Quarter" and other stories made it clear that this detective, who first appeared in A Study in Scarlet, attended Oxford.
B.answer: Sherlock Holmes (accept either underlined portion)

C.question: After losing a scholarship to Oxford, this creation of Colin Dexter joined the Thames [temz] Valley Police; he is notable for his interests in crosswords, opera, and classic cars.
C.answer: Inspector Endeavour Morse (accept either underlined name)

questions.prompt: Pliny [PLY-nee] the Elder records this sculptor's claim that, while his predecessors "had made men as they really are," this man "made them as they appeared to be."  For 10 points each -

A.question: What sculptor's work likely survives only in copies, most notably a marble after his The Scraper pulled from a basement in Trastevere [trah-STEV-uh-ray] in 1849?
A.answer: Lysippos (or Lysippus)

B.question: Lysippos differed from the earlier master Polykleitos [pahl-ee-KLYE-tuss] by making the head one-eighth rather than one-seventh of the body; such ancient systems of human proportions are known by this term, from the Greek for "standard."
B.answer: canon(s) of (body) proportions (or aesthetic canon(s))

C.question: Lysippos was the court sculptor for this ancient conqueror, who is shown on a sarcophagus excavated from Sidon [SYE-dahn] fighting the Persians at the Battle of Issus.
C.answer: Alexander the Great (or Alexander III of Macedon or Aléxandros ho Mégas; prompt on "Alexander")

questions.prompt: This author died of tuberculosis in 1924, leaving his novel about K.'s struggles with a shadowy bureaucracy unfinished.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this author of The Trial and The Castle.
A.answer: Franz Kafka

B.question: Though Kafka left instructions that his unfinished works were to be burned, this man, Kafka's literary executor, published them posthumously instead.
B.answer: Max Brod [broht]

C.question: While visiting Brod, Kafka met this woman, who later became his fiancée.  A 1967 book collects some of Kafka's letters to this woman, who is the dedicatee of his story "The Judgment."
C.answer: Felice Bauer (accept either underlined portion; prompt on "F.")

questions.prompt: This book refers to Robert McNamara [MAK-nuh-mair-uh] as the "can-do man" in the "can-do era."  For 10 points each-

A.question: Name this 1972 David Halberstam book that profiles a group of young advisors in the Defense Department who crafted flawed Vietnam War policies.
A.answer: The Best and the Brightest

B.question: David Halberstam's The Best and the Brightest profiles the "Whiz Kids" who came to Washington with this Democratic president in 1961.
B.answer: John F(itzgerald) Kennedy (or JFK)

C.question: Many of the Defense Department's "Whiz Kids" came from this nonprofit think tank, a corporation founded by the Douglas Aircraft Company in 1948.

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about video games in which players must take unusual physical actions to progress:

A.question: In a Sega Genesis game starring this superhero team, characters such as Wolverine, Cyclops, a nd Nightcrawler must "reset" a computer by pressing the console's actual reset button.
A.answer: X-Men

B.question: Phantom Hourglass, a 2007 handheld entry in this series, required players to physically close and open the DS to copy a map.
B.answer: The Legend of Zelda (accept The Legend of Zelda: Phantom Hourglass)

C.question: This NES adventure game, which stars the yo-yo-wielding Mike Jones, requires players to reveal a code by physically dipping a paper letter included with the game in water.

questions.prompt: This series illustrates the emergence of modern multinationals using the examples of the Dutch conglomerate Philips and the fictional "UGE" ["U-G-E"].  For 10 points each -

A.question: Identify this TV series.  Margaret Thatcher personally invited Milton Friedman to England to debate with Nicholas Kaldor after decrying this series as "biased."
A.answer: The Age of Uncertainty

B.question: The BBC styled The Age of Uncertainty as the "personal view" of its presenter, this liberal economist who wrote The Affluent Society.
B.answer: John Kenneth Galbraith [gahl-BRAYTH] (or Ken Galbraith)

C.question: In 1980 PBS aired this series, Friedman's pro-market rebuttal to The Age of Uncertainty, which was accompanied by a book of the same title co-written by Rose Friedman.
C.answer: Free to Choose(: A Personal Statement)

questions.prompt: This solvent has been considered for the synthesis of MOFs ["moffs"] due to its green properties and adjustable solvent power.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this solvent, a supercritical fluid used in many extraction methods, such as the decaffeination of coffee.
A.answer: supercritical carbon dioxide (or sCO2 or supercritical CO2)

B.question: Supercritical carbon dioxide has applications in these processes for washing clothing without water, which normally use the solvent tetrachloroethylene [teh-truh-klor-oh-EH-thuh-leen], or "perc."
B.answer: dry cleaning

C.question: Other candidates for green solvents include these substances, which are often based on EMIM ["E-M-I-M"].  Unlike deep eutectic solvents, the components of these substances are exclusively discrete.
C.answer: ionic liquids (or ILs; prompt on "ionic solvents")

questions.prompt: A sonnet dedicated to this poet begins "we laid him in a cool and shadowed grove / one evening in the dreamy scent of thyme."  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this poet who himself wrote a sonnet beginning "if I should die, thin k only this of me: / that there's some corner of a foreign field / that is forever England."
A.answer: Rupert (Chawner) Brooke

B.question: This World War II-era poet wrote "Sonnet to Rupert Brooke" as well as the sonnet "High Flight," which begins "oh! I have slipped the surly bonds of Earth."
B.answer: John Gillespie Magee (Jr.)

C.question: Brooke was called "the handsomest young man in England" by this poet of "An Irish Airman Foresees His Death" and "Easter, 1916."

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about statuses of near-citizenship:

A.question: Aristotle was among the prominent members of Athenian society who held this status as a long-term foreign resident of Athens who was subject to many of the burdens, but few of the privileges, of citizenship.
A.answer: metic(s) (or metoikos)

B.question: Civitas sine suffragio [SIH-vee-tas SEE-nah soo-FRAH-jee-oh], or "citizenship without the vote," was a category in this republic, in which proposed citizenship reform helped lead to the downfall of Gaius Gracchus.
B.answer: Roman Republic (or Rome or Res publica Romana)

C.question: Between the World Wars, stateless persons could travel and be recognized as refugees with passports named for this Norwegian explorer.
C.answer: Fridtjof Nansen (or Fridtjof Wedel-Jarlsberg Nansen; accept Nansen passport(s))

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about the process known as "Megxit":

A.question: "Megxit" refers to this man and his wife Meghan Markle opting to withdraw from the British royal family in 2020.
A.answer: Prince Harry (or Harry, Duke of Sussex)

B.question: The term "Megxit," a reference to "Brexit," was coined by this tabloid newspaper, which launched a Sunday edition in 2012 after the fallout from the News of the World phone hacking scandal.
B.answer: The Sun (accept The Sun on Sunday)

C.question: In October 2020 Harry and Meghan founded this non-profit organization based in Beverly Hills to replace the now-defunct Sussex Royal Foundation.

questions.prompt: Actor Steve Martin, who plays this instrument, created an annual prize for players of it, whose past recipients include Danny Barnes and Rhiannon Giddens.  For 10 points eac h-

A.question: Name this circular-bodied string instrument used in bluegrass music.
A.answer: banjo(s)

B.question: The prize's 2019 winner, Victor Furtado [fur-TAH-doh], plays this rhythmic banjo style that, unlike the Scruggs and other styles, relies primarily on downpicking.
B.answer: clawhammer banjo (accept framming or frailing or banging or thrashing or thumb-cocking)

C.question: When Furtado was twelve, he was invited to perform with Mike Snider at this weekly country music concert based in Nashville.
C.answer: Grand Ole Opry (prompt on "Opry") [Furtado was 19 when he won the prize.]

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about 2018 Broadway revivals centered on gay characters:

A.question: In 2018 a revival-record eleven Tony nominations were received by what two-part "Gay Fantasia on National Themes" by Tony Kushner?
A.answer: Angels in America(: A Gay Fantasia on National Themes)

B.question: An all-gay cast appeared in a revival of a pioneering Mart Crowley play titled for the "boys" in one of these groups.  This kind of group is mentioned in the title of a history of the AIDS crisis by Randy Shilts.
B.answer: bands (accept The Boys in the Band or And the Band Played On)

C.question: For a 2018 revival, Harvey Fierstein ["fire"-steen] created an updated version of this Tony-winning set of plays, which premiered in 1982.

questions.prompt: This relationship can be measured with Spearman's rho.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this relationship that, according to an adage, does not imply causation.
A.answer: correlation (accept linear correlation or rank correlation or correlation does not imply causation)

B.question: Spearman's rho is a statistic described by this word because no assumptions are made about the joint distribution of the two variables.  Statistical tests described by this thirteen -letter word are also called distribution free tests.
B.answer: nonparametric (accept nonparametric statistic or nonparametric tests)

C.question: Unlike Pearson's r, Spearman's rho is able to discriminate between the data sets in this English statistician's "quartet" designed to demonstrate the limitations of summary statistics.

questions.prompt: The Tuva Republic lies at the border between these two countries.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name these two countries.  The Selenga River originates in one of them before flowing north into Lake Baikal in the other.
A.answer: Russia (or Russian Federation or Rossiya or Rossiyskaya Federatsiya)   Mongolia (or Mongol Uls)

B.question: Tuva's cultural touchstones include khöömei [koo-may], a technique of this type of singing.  Its varieties include the whistle-like sygyt [suh-guht] and the ultra-deep kargyraa [kar-guh-rah].
B.answer: throat singing (accept overtone singing or chanting or harmonic singing)

C.question: An international festival of throat singing is held every other year in this capital of Tuva.

questions.prompt: This monarch shaved and broke a beard vow, leading Louise of Savoy to observe that kingly bonhomie [bon-oh-mee] lay "not in the beards but in the hearts."  For 10 points each -

A.question: According to Robert III de la Marck [roh-bair "the third" deh la "mark"], what king became upset after losing a wrestling match at a sumptuous 1520 diplomatic summit?
A.answer: Henry VIII ["the eighth"] of England (prompt on "Henry")

B.question: The beard kerfuffle at the Field of the Cloth of Gold was resolved when Thomas Boleyn blamed th e shaving on this woman, Henry's first wife, who was from Aragon.
B.answer: Catherine of Aragon (or Catalina de Aragón)

C.question: Catherine entreated Henry to spurn an alliance with Francis in favor of Charles V ["the fifth"], who had been elected Holy Roman Emperor over both men on the strength of bribes and his sister's marriage to this king of Bohemia.
C.answer: Louis II (of Hungary) (accept Ludvik II or Ludovik II or Lajos II; prompt on "Louis" or "Lud(o)vik" or "Lajos")

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about the early years of the Associated Press Athlete of the Year award:

A.question: The first male winner was Pepper Martin, who like Dizzy Dean was one of the players Branch Rickey assembled to play for this National League franchise's 1930s "Gashouse Gang" teams.
A.answer: St. Louis Cardinals (accept either underlined portion; accept Cards)

B.question: Both the first male and female repeat winners, Don Budge and Alice Marble, were selected for their accomplishments in this sport, also played by later winners Chris Evert [EV-urt] and Serena Williams.
B.answer: tennis (accept tennis players)

C.question: The first male golfer to win the award was this Italian-American.  His win at the 1935 Masters made him the first player to win a career grand slam consisting of all four modern professional majors.

questions.prompt: Jonathan Schaffer's paper "On What Grounds What" notes that people who make claims about grounding often "retreat to" claims about this relation.  For 10 points each -

A.question: According to the Stanford Encyclopedia, property A has what relation to property B if "there cannot be an A difference without a B difference"?
A.answer: supervenience ["super"-VEEN-ee-entz] (accept strong or weak supervenience; accept answers indicating forms of the word supervene such as supervening)

B.question: Dispute exists about whether supervenience avoids or entails this process, which explains complex phenomena, such as consciousness, in terms of "lower level" phenomena, such as physical activity in the brain.
B.answer: reduction (accept reducing or reductionism or reductionist(s); accept strong or weak reductionism)

C.question: David Lewis named a type of supervenience after this Scottish author of An Enquiry Concerning Human Understanding.
C.answer: David Hume (or David Home; accept Humean supervenience)

questions.prompt: These objects correspond to terminals in a programming language's context -free grammar.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name these objects that a scanner or lexer ["lex-er"] generates by matching regular expressions to strings in an input file.
A.answer: tokens (or lexemes)

B.question: These programs build abstract syntax trees, or ASTs, from input tokens.  These subprograms of compilers are classified by whether they build the AST from the top-down or from the bottom-up.
B.answer: parsers

C.question: Source code is compiled to bytecode, which is then interpreted in the standard C implementation of this programming language whose name derives from a British comedy group.
C.answer: Python (accept CPython; do not accept or prompt on "Monty Python")

questions.prompt: Tertullian suggested that this term could refer to some form of ear or head pain.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Give the term from the King James Bible used to name an ailment in a New Testament book.  After asking God to remove this thing, the man suffering from it is told "my grace is sufficient for thee."
A.answer: thorn in the flesh (or Paul's thorn)

B.question: Paul describes his thorn in his second epistle to these people.  Paul's first epistle to them says that "love is patient, love is kind; it does not envy."
B.answer: Corinthians (accept First Corinthians or Second Corinthians or First Epistle to the Corinthians or Second Epistle to the Corinthians)

C.question: Paul's thorn may have been a lingering form of this condition, which Paul briefly suffers in Acts of the Apostles.  Jesus heals Bartimaeus of this condition in Jericho.

questions.prompt: When Paris's Palais Garnier [pah-lay garn-YAY] held its inaugural concert in 1875, Gabrielle Krauss played the title character of an opera by this composer.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this composer whose 1835 grand opera La Juive [lah zhweev] is known in English as The Jewess.
A.answer: Fromental Halévy [hah-lay-VEE] (or Jacques-François-Fromental-Élie Halévy)

B.question: This tenor performer's final role was as Eléazar [el-ee-ah-sar] in Halévy's La Juive.  His 1903 RCA Victor recording of the aria "Vesti la giubba" was the first-ever record to sell a million copies.
B.answer: Enrico Caruso

C.question: Halévy's nephew Ludovic [loo-doh-veek] was the librettist for this composer's comic operas La Belle Hélène [lah bel ay-LEN] and Orpheus in the Underworld.

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about the career of Illinois senator Paul Douglas:

A.question: In the 1930s Douglas lobbied for the "Chicago plan" to severely restrict the multiplying activities of these institutions, including banning their "fractional reserve" structure.
A.answer: (lending) banks (accept savings and loans or savings banks)

B.question: Interpretations differ on why Douglas presented a pitcher of orange juice during this 1957 event, which began on August 28 and lasted just over 24 hours.
B.answer: Strom Thurmond's filibuster of the Civil Rights Act of 1957 (prompt on "filibuster"; accept James Strom Thurmond Sr. in place of "Strom Thurmond")

C.question: While a professor of economics at Amherst in 1928, Douglas co-authored an article with this fellow economist on the production of output by two inputs, such as capital and labor.
